# Distributions of genetic markers in healthy patients

Information about the the respective genetic information and the allele distribution of different populations comes from the 1000 Human Genome Project. We have retrieved the information with the use of ensembl.org.

The information about the genetic markers will be presented using the VCF format: `(CHROM POS ID REF ALT)`, where:\newline

* `CHROM` - chromosome identifier
* `POS` - reference position
* `ID` - genetic marker identifier
* `REF` - reference base(s) 
* `ALT` - alternative base(s)


# rs2476601

The information about this genetic marker can be found here: 
https://www.ensembl.org/Homo_sapiens/Variation/Population?db=core;r=1:113834446-113835446;v=rs2476601;vdb=variation;vf=166892

VCF: `1  113834946  rs2476601  A  G,T` 

```{r rs2476601_data, echo=FALSE}
region <- c("ALL", "AFR", "AMR", "EAS", "EUR", "SAS")
A_freq <- c(0.027, 0.003, 0.036, 0.000, 0.094, 0.013)
G_freq <- c(0.973, 0.997, 0.964,  1.000, 0.906, 0.987)

AA_freq <- c(0.001 , 0.00, 0.003 ,  0.000, 0.004 , 0.00)
AG_freq <- c(0.052 , 0.006 , 0.066 ,  0.000, 0.181 , 0.027)
GG_freq <- c(0.946 , 0.994 , 0.931 ,  1.000, 0.815 , 0.973)

data.rs2476601.rep <- data.frame(region, A_freq, G_freq, AA_freq, AG_freq, GG_freq)
print(data.rs2476601.rep)
```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
data.plot <- data.rs2476601.rep[, c("region", "AA_freq", "AG_freq", "GG_freq")]

data.plot <- pivot_longer(data.plot, c("AA_freq", "AG_freq", "GG_freq"), values_to = "frequency", names_to = "allel")

rs2476601.plot <- ggplot(data=data.plot, aes(x=region, y=frequency, fill=allel)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity", width=0.7)+
  scale_fill_discrete(labels=c("AA", "AG", "GG"))+
  xlab("data origin")+
  theme_minimal()
  
rs2476601.plot
```

# Estimated distributions of genetic markers in healthy patients

In the beginning we have to prepare data. We are filtering data to get data about healthy patients and then remove missing data.
```{r}
data_HC <- data[data$Group == 'HC', ]
head(data_HC)

sum(is.na(data_HC)) 

data_HC <- na.omit(data_HC)
sum(is.na(data_HC))

dim(data_HC) 
```

Now we are going to create new variable for each allele and calculate distribution of them. Then we compare results with distributions from repository.

# rs2476601
```{r}
data.rs2476601 <- data_HC$rs2476601
unique(data.rs2476601)

table.rs2476601 <- table(data.rs2476601)
num.alleles.rs2476601 <- 2 * sum(table.rs2476601)
numA.alleles.rs2476601 <- sum(data.rs2476601=='AG')

proportion.allelesA.rs2476601 <- numA.alleles.rs2476601/num.alleles.rs2476601

proportion.rs2476601 <- data.frame(
  region = "sample",
  A_freq = proportion.allelesA.rs2476601,
  G_freq = 1 - proportion.allelesA.rs2476601
)

proportion.rs2476601
```
```{r}

```

# Genotype distribution for HC group
From previous slide we know amount of each genotype (got it from table function). Now
we are going to calculate frequencies of each genotype and then compare it with expectations from
the Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium using chi-square test.

## rs2476601

```{r}
freq.rs2476601 <- prop.table(table.rs2476601)
freq.rs2476601["AA"] <- 0.

freq.rs2476601
theo.prob.rs2476601 <- c(proportion.allelesA.rs2476601^2, 2*proportion.allelesA.rs2476601*(1-proportion.allelesA.rs2476601),(1-proportion.allelesA.rs2476601)^2)
theo.prob.rs2476601 <- theo.prob.rs2476601[c(2,3,1)] # sorting
theo.prob.rs2476601

table.rs2476601["AA"] <- 0.
chisq.test(x=table.rs2476601, p=theo.prob.rs2476601)
```

## rs3087243
```{r}
freq.rs3087243 <- prop.table(table.rs3087243)
freq.rs3087243
theo.prob.rs3087243 <- c(proportion.allelesA.rs3087243^2, 2*proportion.allelesA.rs3087243*(1-proportion.allelesA.rs3087243),(1-proportion.allelesA.rs3087243)^2)
theo.prob.rs3087243
```

# Genotype Distribution Between CFS and HC

To test if the genotype distribution between CFS and HC is significantly different we used the Chi-Squared test and the Fisher's exact test. According to https://www.ccjm.org/content/84/9_suppl_2/e20 if substantial (above 20%) of expected cell counts is less than 5, the Fisher's exact test should be used.

## rs2476601
```{r}
p.values <- c()

contingency_table <- table(data$Group, data$rs2476601)
contingency_table
fisher_test_result <- fisher.test(contingency_table)
fisher_test_result

p.values <- c(p.values,fisher_test_result$p.value)
```

# Bonferroni's Correction
Now we can apply the Bonferroni's correction to adjust the p-values.
```{r}
adjusted_p_values <- p.adjust(p.values, method = "bonferroni")
adjusted_p_values


gene_names <- c("rs2476601", "rs3087243", "rs3807306", "rs1800629", "rs1799724")
tests_used <- c("Fisher's Exact Test", "Chi-squared Test", "Chi-squared Test", "Fisher's Exact Test", "Chi-squared Test")

result_table <- data.frame(
  Genetic_Marker = gene_names,
  Test_Used = tests_used,
  P_Value = p.values,
  Adjusted_P_Value = adjusted_p_values
)

result_table
```
As we can see, there is a significant difference in genotype distribution between CFS and HC for rs3087243 after Bonferroni correction. For all other genetic markers there are no significant differences in genotype distributions between the groups.

# Creating models

Next, we created models using "Group" as the outcome variable and adjusting for 'Gender'. 

## rs2476601
```{r}
new_data <- na.omit(data)
new_data$Group_binary <- as.factor(ifelse(new_data$Group == "CFS", 1, 0))

new_data$rs2476601 <- ifelse(new_data$rs2476601 == "GG", 2, ifelse(new_data$rs2476601=='AG',1,0))
mod.rs2476601 <- glm(new_data$Group_binary~new_data$rs2476601+new_data$Gender, family=binomial(link='probit'))
summary(mod.rs2476601)
```

```{r}
accuracy
```
